review_title: Not the place it used to be
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Cambridge, England
pros: Wonderful people Nice food Good work life balance
cons: The merger caused a massive culture shift for former assessment employees who are now left feeling like the poor relative. Senior positions all seem to go to Press employees and there is very little attempt to bring genuine cohesion to the two organisations or acknowledge the damage that it is doing to the culture. It no longer feels like a place that cares about it’s employees, there is lip service from the c-suite execs but while they all benefit from their huge bonuses it is hard to feel they really care or understood what it is like for employees anywhere else. There was a feeling that merging would be easy so even though from a technical point of view it has happened from the human point of view it is more divided than it ever was meaning people feel left out and unwelcome in future direction for the organisation.

pros: Normal company perks at corporate level. Some REALLY great people.
cons: Systems are outdated, and there's a huge backlog of issues becuase of this. Constantly felt like we were fighting against snr management to get action taken and the merge of assessment and Press was a glacial activity. My manager was micromanaging everything I did, but others across the business were great.

job_title: Content & Digital Marketing in Cambridge, England
pros:
* Pay reasonable (for publishing) 
* Good colleagues 
* Good food & drink facilities 
* Close-ish to station
cons:
* Highly silo'd structure, with major barriers between divisions and departments, e.g. between technology and publishing. 

* Inert, sometimes authoritarian senior management (one director in particular appeared to treat most other staff, male in particular, with something approaching contempt) 

* Keen to promote women - great if you're a woman but opportunities for men seemed limited. (This was quite overt: one time there was a communication more or less saying that in future we'll be looking to promote women first; a follow up reassured that it would all be done within the law regarding sex discrimination.)

* Limited scope for substantive career dev't discussions, in my experience, even at annual review 

* Managers often seemed essentially uninterested in their staff 

* Bottom line: it's a turn up and do your work sort of place, not a place to have exciting ideas!

review_title: Organisation is not customer focused and doesn't care for lower banded staff's opinions!
pros: Good benefits. Nice buildings to work in. Diversity is excellent.
cons: Since the merging of the assessment and press side there is no cohesion between the two. I'm a customer service type employee and day to day I deal with more customer dissatisfaction than anywhere I've ever worked! CUPA have no interest in their customers nor sorting out their queries. When I try to make management aware of this, I have been basically told I'm too helpful, I care too much and I'm not to agree with the customer being justifiably frustrated with our organisations poor customer service. It was inferred I just need to be a type of robot with my replies (this being the case, they should just automate the system, if they don't want the human touch, which clearly they do not).  Therefore, they don't care about getting customer complaints. They don't train their employees properly. Poor senior managers get away with being bad at their job and seemingly have no accountability. My motivation is zero now. I have lost all respect for this organisation and cannot wait to leave as soon as I'm able to!

review_title: We are there to make a profit for Cambridge University ....

review_title: Still a tale of two (good!) companies
pros: The English department has a very respectable mission statement and the majority of people work very hard at all levels to fulfil that mission statement. The offices in Cambridge have a positive and friendly vibe when enough people are working in them, and I have made several friends for life by working here. The business is finally making a real push towards improvements in building a diverse and inclusive working culture. Management and colleagues were supportive and empathetic when I had debilitating health issues, and I have seen teams rally around other colleagues in times of need - on both a personal and professional level - which I've seldom seen in other organisations. Office facilities are generally top-notch and clean. Union presence is a great boon to the workforce. By far and away, the people we work with are the best thing about the business.
cons: It does sometimes feel like we're still in the teething period following our merger, which isn't especially encouraging a couple of years on! People still talk about the organisation as if there are two businesses, rather than one. Some colleagues are now unclear on what's expected of them day-to-day and long-term, whereas before there was clarity. There have been times in the last two years where morale across the business has absolutely plummeted, with no real engagement by leadership to listen and respond to concerns. This hasn't been helped by slim opportunities for career progression and stagnating salaries. A very meeting-heavy working culture, which would be fine if meetings actually resolved anything (which they don't always do... they just lead to more meetings!), and very old-fashioned working practices and processes. The fruits of our labour around EDIB aren't really reflected in our workforce yet, especially at senior management and leadership levels. There has been very inconsistent communication around hybrid / flexible working advice and policies, which has left a lot of colleagues feeling confused and worried, especially when travel, health and financial considerations need to be taken into account (and arguably, prioritised).

review_title: Worse since the merger - taking our rights and cutting our pay
pros:
A lot of colleagues there are great to work with. The work is interesting and can be quite varied.
Middle and upper middle management tends to be fairly decent. Training and development opportunities and efforts to be more inclusive are improving.
cons:
Since Press and Assessment merged, there have been significant efforts to strip important terms and conditions from contracts and make it harder for unions to represent staff. We're also seeing significant real-terms pay cuts at a time when the company is doing well and the cost of living is rising.
The board seems keen to crush the last remaining morale and to ensure that staff joining the company in the future have a much poor deal than existing staff. If you're tired of being lied to and spat on by the government, you'll get the same treatment here by upper management.
There also seems to be an increase in pressure to return to the office, even though Covid numbers are high and the level of presenteeism means that you're likely to catch other viruses from put-upon staff who feel they have to be there.

review_title: Antagonistic, deceptive management, excessive outsourcing and no progression
pros: Staff discount on books published by the organisation.
cons:
Poor pay - This used to be offset by the press being a nice place to work, is now just unpleasant in every regard.

Antagonistic, deceptive management - You have to fight for every little thing, whether it's resources, time or even a reasonable workload, upper management deliberately avoid direct contact with front line employees all the while pocketing excessive bonuses/wages.
While doing this they tout how the "people are important" and "just speak to us if you need extra resource" while taking actions that are the opposite.
When someone leaves it either takes months to advertise/replace or the role is outsourced to Manilla at a fraction of the cost/competence. 
These are the sort of people that will spit in your face and tell you it's rain.

No Progression - self explanatory, lots of nepotism, where there is progression it's based on who knows who, not merit.

The organisation has changed a great deal over the last few years. I used to be proud to work here but now that management is filled with Yes men who's solution to any problem or issue is to ignore it and let it fester. 
Here's hoping the University proper intervenes soon, turfs these people out and restore the organisation to a fraction of its former glory.

Opportunities to move and increase your skills with the large company.
Amazing modern Cambridge building (now of course, mostly standing empty!)
cons:
The merger is showing up some significant cultural differences and it does not feel as is these are being addressed - just brushed under the carpet.
There is a sense that the merged senior leadership team feel pretty 'male, pale and stale'.
You have to look out for yourself, because despite what the company says, HR are not there to support your career.
The group faces increasingly stiff external competition from digital companies who are leaner, smarter, faster and more agile - it is in danger of falling far behind.
There are no consequences - either for doing an outstanding job, or for doing a terrible one.
A very political atmosphere which takes up much of the senior management time and effort

review_title: Lovely building, culture needs a lot of work
pros: Really nice building and lovely food. Some of my colleagues were really nice and supportive, but they were mostly in business and marketing. I enjoyed meeting stakeholders and the regional teams.
cons: Unfortunately the culture was not what I expected - there was quite a lot of negativity from colleagues in my team, a lot of resentment and tension and senior managers did not address this.  Some of this was personal - which I found inappropriate and unprofessional.  I had a pretty miserable year and found it very tough at times, but I would like to think that it was just my team and I was unlucky.  I heard that other areas of the business don't have the same issues.   A lot of people seemed to be on long term sick so I am not sure what that says about it as a place to work. The company does make a lot of noise about well-being and mental health though and is training its managers. Maybe they should address the causes of the stress though, which is often poor management and miscommunication.

pros: Free gym access,  reasonable pension scheme. The people are lovely and senior editors in particular have a wealth of knowledge about publishing and their own subject matters, which makes them a joy to learn from. Depending on your manager, flexible working patterns are possible and overtime is rarely expected. There is a sense of pride in working for such a historic institution.
cons: The pay is low for Cambridge, and the pay rise system is geared against junior roles. Bizarre attitude to investment – several million pounds are being overspent on various internal technology projects which as far as I can tell, have made little improvement to the actual business of selling products. This is frustrating to see when reams of your colleagues are made redundant on a regular basis. There is also very little investment into relatively small expenditures like staff training, and, as others have said, it feels quite stagnant in terms of product or business development. Far too many meetings which don’t amount to any actual outcomes and too many things are done inefficiently ‘because that’s how they’ve always been done’.

review_title: Excellent place to work. Good work/life balance.
pros: Real support system throughout the team. Good line management, with clear expectations set, while still maintaining a friendly and approachable manner. Never felt too stressed, and the work was distributed well between sub team members. The organisation frequently puts on great events, and encourages you to get involved. The new offices are amazing, and promote a great working environment.
cons:
Workload isn't very balanced, but this is due to the intense summer working period, and quieter winter period. The workload didn't feel very steady, it was all at once or little. But this gave good time to work on other things and get organised. 

I found it a bit strange that I would constantly be emailing the same people each week in teams on the same floor as me, and I would never meet them in person, or know what they looked like. I think the departments should set up a meeting where everyone puts a face to a name, so it's more personable. This encourages better working relationships, and its less of a sterile interaction over email.

pros: Long history of sincere mission-led publishing. Lots of colleagues with integrity, brains, and drive, who take pride in good work. Great authors who are creating the ideas of the future. Surviving pockets of excellence. For someone at entry level, or just above entry level, provided you hit a pocket of excellence, it is still one of the best places to learn about high-quality publishing from smart people with a lot of experience.
cons: It's not clear how long any pockets of excellence can survive, and even now above entry level I would not recommend CUP to anyone with ambitions to publish high-quality, innovative content. In recent years, honest but somewhat sleepy management has been replaced with chancers out to drain the brand, treating it as bottomless well. IP is being handed over in ill-advised partnerships, and vast sums of money and time have been squandered on dysfunctional systems; to compensate, there are deep, damaging cuts where it most hurts: the development and production of content and marketing.

pros: Smart, curious colleagues. Top-notch, engaged authors. Although new management is trying to build a content farm, it's not there yet; so most things you'll work on are of good quality and can make a difference in the world. Underneath the constant spreadsheet wankery is meaningful work. And you can always hope the Syndicate will wake up and make a change. It happened before.
cons: Current upper management doesn't have a clue. They think that putting something in an MS Office document makes it "work". Elaborate restructuring planned in powerpoint, with no sanity checking against real work requirements, has been a disaster. Heedless repricing and rediscounting cranked through Excel, with no feel for the market, is a disaster. The most rewarded behaviour is the pursuit of meaningless internal targets. I'd wager good money that HR has been given the target of getting the Press to 2.5 stars before the fiscal year ends -- hence the laughable, barely written positive reviews that keep appearing.

review_title: A great place to work, that is working hard to make things even better
pros:
My line manager is excellent. She has encouraged my growth and confidence, as well as being flexible when the needs of my (young) family required.

Alongside this, Cambridge Assessment has a real commitment to developing their staff. Whether that is through learning and development, wellbeing initiatives or of particular importance in my roll, access to relevant equipment and software.

Collaboration is one of our values - and you see this in action all the time as people work hard together across the different parts of our business.

I feel secure and supported at Cambridge Assessment.
cons:
There are times when I think we could do things quicker.

As well as having offices in Coventry, and overseas we currently have many offices in central Cambridge which, whilst it has its advantages, is not always ideal. We are, however, due to move to a brand new Cambridge headquarters soon (Q1 2018).

It currently takes me about 45 minutes to travel to the office. It would be great to have a shorter commute.

review_title: Could be a truly great organisation but has work to do to achieve this
pros:
Great colleagues, in particular those with great technical expertise and passion for education who are most closely involved in developing and delivering exams, curricula and teacher support worldwide

Good products and brands, recognised globally

Superb market positions across the world. 

Good building and subsidised canteen
cons:
Inability to deliver major IT projects - consume vast amount of time, effort and money and result in immense waste and frustration

Operates as separate businesses who do roughly the same thing but who all try to do it separately

Overstaffed in some areas with people who lack commercial expertise

A culture that doesn't encourage people to raise concerns or issues

No real sense of being valued by Cambridge University
'
A reluctance to listen to people or recognise expertise  from outside 'education'

Paralytically slow decision making, an organisational structure that hasn't changed for 20 years

review_title: A company that values and looks after their staff
pros: Free on-site gym, bar, exercise classes, canteen, day off each to volunteer, quarterly briefings from department heads, bi-annual briefings by CEO, regular newsletter updates with publishing schedule and a lot of filtering down of information to keep everybody informed, staff communities encouraged, active Union, take personal development and training seriously, lots of room for progression
cons: Things seem to move a little slow, publishing activities still seem to have huge lead-times, deadlines with freelancers seem easily pushed, it's taken a little while to catch on with digital. Recent push to introduce performance related pay has caused a standstill on pay-rises and progressions (including adjustments for cost of living)- Union and management unable to agree on how to move forward leaves those not involved with little idea of when things will get sorted.

review_title: With a little bit of luck you can have a lovely career here
pros: Responsibility, flexibility, a changing work environment and business challenges keeping a job fresh and interesting.  There are some lovely and excellent people working here who make great colleagues.
cons: Frustrating if you end up tackling a group of people who resort to the ease of deferring decisions in favour of having another meeting. Things can take ages. Systems and the way they are managed sometimes hinder instead of helping. There's a satisfaction though of sometimes being able to cut through some of this stuff.

pros:
*great benefits
*if you are working with a forward thinking manager, flexible working is a plus
*good caliber of employees 
*good canteen (great staff prices)
*great projects across the board
*global work experience
*well being center with great fitness classes
*well functioning and resourceful new building
*good location (10min walk from Cambridge main train station)
(the cons listed below are gradually improving- to an extent, with new hire of employees in various different sectors with different mindsets)
cons:
*some senior managers are not fit for their position but rather have stayed in the position due to seniority, not merit
*some managers lack the courage to voice and propose robust ideas (fear of rocking the boat?)
*a mixture of old school thinking and progressive innovations; resistance for change in some departments
*many colleagues lack basic commercial awareness

pros: Food served is fantastic - great choice, quality and value. Over the top subsidy given it’s a part of publicly funded institution, but enjoy it.
cons:
The hastily appointed 2nd choice CEO stated his favorite 3 things about the job are the food offering; the business-class travel (which is ridiculously excessive and has no oversight in this place); and then he finally remembered what he was there for: the opportunity to help people prove their skills to the world...  

Pitiful lack of business-sense with a bloated finance dept stuck in 1980s. OCR/CIE/Camb English spend entire time fighting each other - the competition must be laughing. 

At one director’s leaving speech the CEO said “all the best senior employees leave after 2 years”!! Surprised he admitted that but he’s right - just weak leadership remain. 
10 out of 12 previous CEO’s reports have left within a year of this CEO starting, replaced with his friends: people who just smile and won’t dare challenge. 

Such a shame: this place deserves better.

pros:
Onsite gym and restaurant (reasonable priced food).
Colleagues very helpful and friendly.
Reasonable site in City with parking and easy walking distance from train station, close to guided bus route.
cons:
Lot of empire building by middle management, this results in the the main Asset (the people on the floor) being overlooked especially when certain managers know less about the job than those they manage.
Fear that if they continue in the way the business has in later years there will be an exodus of knowledgable and loyal staff.

pros: Flexible working hours, On site facilities (such as Gym, Tennis/Football courts and Bar), Friendly atmosphere and People,
cons: Confusing Management Structure, Lack of opportunities to progress, Consultant culture, Email Culture, Below Average pay, Lack of clear direction from Senior Management, Confused product markets, Cutting Corners and Costs over Quality, Regular Outsourcing of Jobs, general lack of motivation for staff.

pros:
Collegiate vibe is nice. 

Work/life balance is reasonable for most. 

Some genuine people with good intentions. 

Coffee is pretty alright.
cons:
Overwhelmingly white - I cannot think of one single non-white person in the Cambridge branch with any real power. This is shameful. 

Nasty blame culture permeates the entire place to the very highest levels. 

Bullying also seems to be on the rise. 

Too much change for the organisation to absorb. 

Too many overpaid ineffective contractors and consultants who often make things worse. 

Weak out of touch leadership throughout - especially at the very top. 

Hopeless HR department exist only to protect senior management. 

Disastrous SAP programme. How does the CIO still retain his job??

review_title: Such a shame as it has potential
pros:
The people on the ground make this place.
The pension scheme, gym, canteen and coffee areas are also great.
I really have a true circle of friends here who I miss.
cons:
Senior Management are not engaged with the guys on the ground. They also do not take accountability for anything and almost blame those doing the real work.

Meetings culture... I think the senior management need to analyse how much they waste on meetings after meetings.

People on the ground are often disrespected and not listened to. I remember a meeting I had with the CIO where I had to raise my hand to talk.

pros: The Press has a very well educated, friendly, committed staff and a mission that is worthy. It produces content to be proud of. I had many happy years working there.
cons:
The Press is going through a difficult time which is to be expected given the demands that the digital revolution has put on the publishing industry as a whole. Additionally, a lot of the systems in place have needed updating which has put a lot of strain on budgets and staff. There have been a number of painful restructures and redundancies.
In recent years there has been a culture of micromanagement from the top down; most decisions are questioned by directors, making it impossible for teams to thrive and deliver. 
In general, staff members feel underappreciated.

review_title: Proud of how we have pulled together
pros:
With the implementation of a new Values structure, the movement from the annual performance review to the agile 'Continuous Conversations' format, it feels like we are moving in the right direction.

Our global organisation has been put to the test in these recent Covid times and the speed at which those who could perform their roles at home were deployed and supported was amazing. Our well being has been genuinely high on the agenda and communications have been human, supportive and timely.

We've also been able to embed the home working policy for all, and flexibility is now the norm. At no time have we felt pressured to return - it is a gradual and safe return, for those who feel comfortable doing so.
cons: Nothing worth noting in the scheme of things. We've really shown what we are made of.

review_title: Great sense of history, with a sense of change for the future
pros:
- The people are great, with a real mix of skills and expertise
- The work is interesting and varied
- Working at an internationally-renowned global brand helps career development
- People who work here are generally really well looked after compared to other organisations
- Good work/life balance
- Supportive and approachable senior management team
- Great sense of change at the moment, also in the publishing industry more generally (which brings with it both pros and cons)
- Global reach
- Well respected within the publishing industry
- Digital transition
- Responsible business who cares about doing the right thing, not just hitting targets
cons:
- Decision-making can be slow at times, with not very clear processes in place
- The level of change going on (also in the publishing industry more generally) can make it a challenging atmosphere at times

review_title: The culture is not for everyone
pros: The site is large and pleasant. The free gym and subsidised canteen are clear benefits. The flexible hours come in very handy.
cons:
If you don't have left-wing (perhaps even far-left) views, you could be in trouble if you ever get found out. You will be socially ostracised and blanked by people who walk past you. The culture, in reality, is very narrow. If there's tolerance, it's a one-way street. College campus-style activism is common and encouraged. 

Due to the fact most people at the very top are men, there is a drive to only promote and employ women at lower levels. That means men at the start of their careers will be overlooked because people who share their gender are already high up, meaning they can't be. In my department, a male hasn't been employed in years.

pros:
subsidised canteen 
gym/running club on site 
Flexible working in some departments
Various lunch time events (organised by staff)
Looks good on your cv.
cons:
Amount of training offered differs amongst departments, always told there is no budget for external courses. 
Lack of career progression throughout the company.
Number of services are now offshored which has on occasion resulted in job losses and reduction of quality.
HR department are unhelpful and not approachable.
Implementation of the SAP financial system has caused a huge disruption to th business. Despite the overspend, it takes twice as long to process anything and it's not fully installed yet. Absolute nightmare.
Limited car parking spaces.

review_title: A values led organisation  really focused on the well being of its employees
job_title: Senior Manager/Head of Department in Cambridge, England
pros:
As a fairly recent joiner during the COVID pandemic, I have been really impressed by how the organisation supports its employees. Cambridge Assessment already had a strong focus on flexible working, but during the pandemic this has really shined through along with lots of additional support for employees to ensure their well being during this difficult time. 

In addition, the organisation has recently launched a living our values framework which is being embedded across the organisation. While I've had little opportunity to experience them yet, the building and general facilities are also great, with fantastic catering, well being centre and great spaces to work and collaborate in.

The organisation also has a clear strategic vision and communicates this well to its employees so we all know how we are contributing.
cons: So far, i've been really impressed and have no downside to share

pros:
- initially welcoming
- I'm lead to believe its a good name on a CV
- there are some very nice people and departments, Education had some particularly nice individuals who made working at CUP bearable
cons:
- this organisation has many angry people, some openly swear
- there are many staff incapable of doing their job; because they 'get on' with management they are given a lot of slack
- my manager was divisive, controlling and a bully (she bullied a number of people in the her team)
- HR never supports employees below management level, they support tyrant managers by my experience and that of several employees I later found out
- there is a level of racial discrimination - several of the caucasian treated Indian people from the SAP implementation partner were treated terribly (though they did do some sill things, but that no excuse to demean them or anyone)

pros:
The gym, on-site restaurant, the support/services teams, the on-site parking, and definitely the people - the people are genuinely fantastic. You'll miss all of these if you leave.

I was lucky to have a lot of input into my career development.
cons:
- The HiPPO culture: fear of mid-managers to make their own decisions because senior managers can be outspoken and bullish, or just don't allow them to make them.
- Legacy systems - innovation has been thwarted at times by having to incorporate old foundational technology that's not sexy enough to get budget to update/replace.. resulting in vast swathes of work-arounds and old tech exceptions.

pros: The staff is incredibly dedicated.  But everyone is overworked, underpaid, and most are working there because they believe in working for a non for profit - for the good of humanity, unfortunately, the senior management and the CEO do not hold the same values.
cons:
Senior management is utterly useless - short-sighted, risk-averse, out-dated, unauthentic, wedded to old buzzwords and working models, unaware of the real world, and incredibly sexist. Even the Press board is siloed and are all working for different outcomes. It is a mess, and the staff and middle management are suffering. 
Most people are suffering from stress - my doctor told me that he sees 2 to 3 people a week from the Press for stress!!! It is shocking.

review_title: Great for plodders - frustrating for high-achievers...
pros: Final Salary Pension with flexible working arrangements commonplace.  Friendly people.  A culture of "lifers" with a very low staff churn rate.  Very stable and unbeatable job security.
cons: Not challenging.  Politics, politics, politics.  They want plodders who do what they are told - high-achievers will get frustrated.  Medium sized company with large company style red-tape.  The non-profit status allows some really large errors in judgment from senior management to occur without those responsible being held accountable.  Very poor remuneration within the IT sector of the organisation which is limited by company wide paybands

review_title: Surrounded by great people who've turned a corner following lots of change in order to prep the biz for the future.
pros: Collaborative working environment; an Academic MD who genuinely cares about people as she moves the business forward; lovely work colleagues who care passionately about what they do; great content which makes you feel proud to work there; a can-do attitude.
cons: On-going changes in Editorial although necessary make author management harder; some senior managers need to understand that they're in a position to make positive changes (they need to learn to be brave!) Poor systems.

review_title: Avoid if you are passionate about Software Development
pros: The pension is fantastic and the fact that the office is open for only 12 hours a day means that you are unlikely to be doing too much work. The only real pressure is the pressure you put on yourself.
cons: It is my belief that the company does not actually like, or trust, the development department. The developers have been sidelined about how the development process should be changed resulting in an incredibly bureaucratic process that is going to stall development whereas agile development (in my opinion) would deliver significantly better results for them.

pros: There are management who try to stitch things together,  but the press as a whole makes this near impossible.  Flexible working hours.
cons: Meetings culture,  senior managers who really have no idea,  senior directors who should be taken out to the barn.  Criminally negligent,  appalling execution - systems that fail to connect,  impossible to drive business,  customer services stuck in the 1970s.

review_title: Good, but could be so much better!
pros:
- Rewarding work - your job benefits learners, teachers and schools around the world. 
- Friendly atmosphere. Everyone is so nice!
- Great learning and development opportunities. They invest a lot in staff training and development which is great. 
- Flexible working - and they’re getting better.
- Very open to job shadowing, mentor schemes and support networks.
- Fantastic canteens and cafes - a wide range of food and drink options (inc. vegan and paleo).
- New HQ being built and will open in early 2018, meaning all Cambridge-based employees will be under one roof. Exciting times!
cons:
- Very bureaucratic, takes ages to make decisions and get things done.
- Very slow on the uptake in terms of the use of technology to automate processes and support customers. There are still a lot of manual ways of doing things which can be very frustrating. 
- A good place if you want to ‘coast’ in your job and get by doing very little in your role. There are a lot of people who have been there for 10+ years. Long service seems to be rewarded more than hard work in many of these cases. 
- Very traditional and risk-averse. The outcome of the industry we are in I guess. 
- High-achieving staff are not rewarded or compensated for their efforts, so go elsewhere. There needs to be a better way to engage staff that perform above and beyond in their role. 
- Broken performance review model. It has changed a lot over the last few years. The current format does not lend itself to anyone wanting to exceed their job responsibilities. 
- Salaries seem to be dipping and getting lower by the year. Not sustainable when the cost of living in Cambridge is going up each year.

review_title: Some extremely unprofessional people at management level
pros:
The office is well located, the working conditions are comfortable. 
Most colleagues are pleasant and talented.
cons: There are some extremely unprofessional/unethical people at management level. This was flagged to HR (by several colleagues over several months) who has shown absolutely no will whatsoever to tackle the issue.

review_title: Don't judge an [academic] book by its positive-sounding cover
pros: Flexible working around some core hours, supportive of work/life balance if you have the right manager. Have invested a lot in the office environment. Good social facilities. Fairly relaxed working environment when things are going well. Some opportunities to move around different parts of the organisation. Pay increases each year. A sense of cameraderie in adversity.
cons:
- Probably the most (negatively) political organisation I've worked for, though they deny this and pretend everyone is supportive and collaborative across the different functions of the Press. This makes everything slow down to a crawl and destroys trust.

- Whilst there's lots of good, friendly, skilled, constructive people around the place at 'worker'/team level who want to get things done, most of the (many, many) Directors are generally out of their depth and wouldn't last 5 minutes in equivalent positions in commercial organisations. All they know how to do is continually cut costs, generally in the areas that's easiest for them regardless of the consequences. It's at middle-management level where the problem really lies though: it's so "fat" in the middle with ridiculous reporting lines and management waste, damaging cliques, and way too many passengers who seem to have a job for life regardless of what they do (or don't do).

- The way to progress in your career at the Press is to be a 'Yes (wo)man' and not rock the boat or try to change "how things are done round here". If you do, be prepared for a viscious backlash as people protect their little fiefdoms and conspire to put you back in your place. Think your manager/Director will support you? Will they hell!

- A few bad apples ruin things for the good people there, and the good people leave. HR are not interested until their feet are held to the fire but continue to brush these behaviours, including multiple complaints of ongoing bullying, under the carpet. Multiple people have been made seriously ill through this and the lack of support in addressing it. Senior management are equally cowardly and would rather avoid conflict than support their people, which perpetuates the problem but is ok by them as long as they're not making each others' lives difficult.

So by all means, join the Press if you're looking to coast through to retirement as a narcissistic middle-manager who enjoys sucking up to your fellow managers and blaming everyone else below you for your own and the organisations failings.

review_title: Great place to work, lots of benefits, IT opertunities limited

pros: Great management, very laid back and don't have anyone breathing down your back. Very friendly atmosphere, lots of benefits such as on site gym, lots of social groups. Options of using Lynda to work on skills, and encourage personnel development and lots of opportunities to move internally. Flexi time is great if your a morning person or not.
cons:
If you are looking into moving on into IT the press will not have many options , sadly the Press outsource there 1st line and 2nd line to Manilla and only 3rd line is based in the UK, so moving internally is not possible at entry level. I have had to look outside the press, its a shame as id liked to have stayed in the company. 

In regards to my role, our team were understaffed for the majority of time I was there, and despite it was obvious we needed more staff nothing was really ever sorted,  documentation could not be updated and it was not possible to cross train each other due to high volume of tickets which resulted in one person dealing with one area but not able to deal with another and vice versa with a different member of staff, this resulted in certain tickets having to be assigned to a particular individual as they were the only person who knew how to deal with the  type of ticket, it also was an issue when someone was on holiday/sick it meant that some tickets would be put on hold until that person is back or they try and fix the issue despite not having the knowledge to fix the issue.  

When we ask as to when we will get new staff we just get "the management above are still "rightsizing" (basically deciding if they want to spend money on staff or not by analyzing every single bit of data they can find) Its quite clear to us we need staff, so im not sure what more they need to be convinced or why they are taking so long over making a decision, its quite poor that they have taken a good 8 months (still on going) and still nothing has been decided, I am now leaving which means the team will be even more understaffed. I hope that this is sorted for my team as soon as possible.

pros: There is a lot of potential for the organization to do good, to be an industry leader and many fine people working there.

review_title: Its Cambridge's own version of BBC1's W1A
pros:
Working for an organisation that can trace its history back for 500 years is an amazing thing.

There are some immensely talented, imaginative and clever people working there - none in management roles unfortunately.

The site had a compus-like feel, that made the working environment pleasing. This will soon change however once building work starts on the new home for Cambridge Assessment.
cons:
In my five+ years working there the organisation started on a road that I (and it seems many others) fear will see CUP collapse. Where once it stood for academic excellence and well-produced academic publishing, it now stands for dysfunctional management, appalling staff relations and a complete lack of  attention to its product. At the end of the day, the 'brand' survives on trust and respect of its customers, and how can the customers be expected to invest in that when the staff cannot?

Imaginative, clever and innovative staff have little to no means of progression. The organisation is laughably top-heavy, with so many levels of management that no decisions are ever taken in the interests of the long-term future of the company, but only ever in the short-term interests of the managers. Think the wonderful TV Series W1A and you have working at CUP in a nut shell!

There is no appreciation of staff. There is no respect of staff. There is no consideration of staff. It amazes me that management do not see that an under-appreciated, de-motivated, dissatisfied workforce that is coming in to work every single day fearful that there will be yet another round of 're-structures' and management desk-shuffling announced, is not likely to be willing or capable of producing good results. The best asset any company has is its staff, and CUP fail spectacularly to appreciate this. 

It is an organisation where top management have no interest whatsoever in the long-term future of their staff. That means that talented and knowledgeable people, who CUP have 'trained' simply walk out of the door to other companies. That is an enormous waste, and is bleeding the company dry.

The lack of compassion and sensitivity shown is staggering. When the almost weekly 'restructures' are announced and people are yet again concerned for their jobs there is no sensitivity shown or understanding - it always communicated as 'in the best interests of the business'. Of course, it is always notable that what is 'best for the business' is for those on the lowest rungs of the ladder to lose their jobs whilst middle managers (and those higher up, where the biggest mistakes are made of course)  amazingly retain theirs. 

If you wish to work in an environment where you are valued, look elsewhere. If you wish to work in an environment where your imagination and initiative will be rewarded, look elsewhere. If you want to work in an environment where you can be the best you can be, look elsewhere. (f you want to be miserable, over-worked, disrespected, ignored  and treated like an encumbrance to the life of your manager, then roll on up to The University Printing House, as the management   there would love to see you.

pros: Nice offices, good canteen, good transport links. Great colleagues, who are always willing to do their best in a difficult situation.
cons:
Where do you start. When I began working at CUP the job actually wasn't too bad. I had good training, but some of the workflows and systems could have been better, even staff who had worked there for years seemed a bit confused as to what they were supposed to be doing. But overall the workload was about right for a full-time job.

Within a few months the department was subjected to a restructure, which seems to have been very poorly planned and implemented by management, and has caused utter chaos. Many people found their job roles changed and were offered very little training to cope with their new responsibilities. Workloads that staff were expected to deal with rose to totally unmanageable levels, many book projects ground to a virtual halt. Staff have been left feeling very stressed and unsupported, and not surprisingly they have started to leave on a weekly basis, many of whom who had worked at the Press for years and had a wealth of experience (just the people you would want to be keeping). These are then replaced with younger and less experienced staff, brought in on short term contracts, who require training, and so it goes on with an endless cycle of new staff and training - nobody in their right mind would tolerate the current job roles for very long. Management have been very slow to respond, nobody seems to be willing to take control of the situation, little is being done to address what has rapidly become a crisis.
